nytimes_articles.headline: Kind Words and Chaos in Country
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pam and Tommy Hall drove up the street in their silver family van, their hands full with a dozen biscuit-and-sausage sandwiches and their eyes full as well, with tears.   They were neighbors of Michael Jordan's father, James, who was found dead of a gunshot wound to the chest 11 days ago in a South Carolina creek after last being seen on July 22. They had come to the Jordan house in this tiny, close-knit community where the death of a neighbor can have a devastating and lasting impact.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
Myths of the American Indian And Significant Photographs
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"Indian Territories: 20th-century Native-American Artists Dismantle 19th-century Euro-American Myths"
 Renee Fotouhi Fine Art East, 16R Newtown Lane, East Hampton. Thursday to Tuesday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, to 10 P.M. Through Aug. 30. 

Strong images and a high-impact theme combine to make this a particularly substantial exhibition. Its thesis, the distorted interpretations of American Indians that began in the 19th century, is developed by placing paintings, drawings, prints and photographs that contributed to stereotypes next to recent art by tribal members. 

The new work is intended to project the Indian experience and ideology more accurately. In a number of instances, the artist comments directly on what is offensive in the earlier piece.

Organized by Bridget Goodbody with Renee Fotouhi, the exhibition has work by contemporaries with major reputations, including Carl Beam, Edgar Heap of Birds, Fritz Scholder, Jaune Quick-to-See Smith, Kay WalkingStick and Phil Young.

Ethnographic interpretations, land attitudes, spirituality and identity are some of the issues explored. Usually, the messages are clear, but wall texts further underscore the show's politics. A marked degree of stylistic boldness emphasizes the passion in the arguments for revisionism.

One section suggests that the traditional 19th-century expansive landscape scene depicting a seamless harmony between the Indian's world and nature is an erroneous myth. A more intense and symbolic view, represented by Ms. WalkingStick's paintings, transforms cliffs into paired, magical abstract signs and translates earth into a rough, raw, highly visceral and physical surface.

In one of the most striking paintings, "Indian Horse," Ms. Quick-to-See Smith takes on the famous George Catlin, expressing her rage over the artifice in his images by including copies of his drawings and then painting over them. 

There is a comparable mastery of vigorously expressive techniques in two fine pieces by Carl Beam. They also manipulate borrowed images to invent visual metaphors for recognition and nonrecognition of the Indian presence in American society.

Telling contrasts in smaller pieces include David Neel's photograph of a tribal chief in contemplative pose, with eyes lowered and hands clasped.  This is beside a 1917 contrived image of a tribal member gazing outward toward some distant mystical spirit.
Milton Avery and "Magnum Opus"
 Vered Gallery, 66 Park Place, East Hampton. Daily, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Through Aug. 26. 

Admirers of Milton Avery (1885-1965) and his synthesized experiences of nature know that he had such an open approach to what he chose to distill, simplify and rework that it is always possible to come upon surprise paintings. 

One of these, a dark, stacccato, angular interpretation of surf and rocks, is a highlight of this exhibition.  In some respects, it recalls the influence of German Expressionism in drypoints that the artist had made 20 years earlier.

Avery looked for a magic that he called "radiance," and usually achieved this effect by allowing his arbitrarily colored surfaces and forms to seem saturated with light.  Luminosity and tone usually take precedence over description. The large "Sand Bar and Sea," with its vibrant flat, yellow shape suggesting the sand bar, is a good example.

In addition to the oil paintings, there is a sizable group of watercolors that touch on four decades and tend to call attention to how well-suited Avery's goals were to that medium. "Tall Pines" is a striking example of his reduction of images to a kind of semi-symbolism, while "Evening Light" and "Breaking Wave" reveal how close he could come to totally abstract effects.

In "Magnum Opus," 30 examples from a distinguished photography collection show enough of the medium's pivotal history to convey the sense of developing visual codes.  With the earliest years especially, one realizes that this material was part of a revolution in ways of seeing and ways of retaining information.

The survey begins with W. H.Fox Talbot's handsome 1844 calotype "Articles of China," an image that vibrates with historic resonance, and reaches to Cecil Beaton's crisp and moving 1954 view of a Grand Street bridal shop.

Apart from the artistic and technical achievements here, the range of subjects demonstrates the camera's contribution to information and intellectual discourse. The value of genre themes, for example, is presented in John Thompson's dramatically composed scene of activities aboard a Chinese junk in 1868. There are also images that capture horrors of the Civil War, beautiful details of Yellowstone, revelations of archeology and characterisics of exotic journeys.

In a different sense, Harold Edgerton's 12-part sequence featuring a tiny droplet, from 1935, can be considered a landmark inspirational piece, for it claims an abstract and conceptual role for photograpy.
 Rebecca Alston
 Elise Goodheart Fine Arts, 61 Island View Drive, Sag Harbor. Friday to Monday, noon to 5 P.M. Through Aug. 23. 

Ms. Alston makes a good try at updating and giving new vitality to the constructivist mode that had a significant theoretical and philosophical impact earlier in the century. The range of her ideas is impressive, even though the sense of detachment inherent in the geometric approach seems out of step just now.

Clear, crisp definitions and diagonal forces are basic to these paintings and wall reliefs, with every angle important in developing the dynamic tension that serves as a subject.

With strong, unpredictable color and a variety of textures, Ms. Alston seems to test how inventive one can be with a restricted vocabulary. To her credit, she injects a lightness and playfulness into what is usually a serious, humorless approach. 

She may base a relief on a regular grid, then suddenly allow layers of superimposed shapes to thrust out with no respect for boundaries. Another work might solidify shadows and turn them into geometric schemes, and still another might tip forward unexpectedly. Here Ms. Alston might be considered part of the contemporary spirit in the way she suggests irony.

An obvious confidence with space of every type is one of the artist's strong points. A more open piece, closer to wall-mounted sculpture, is a particularly successful departure. Its flame-like protrusion introduces greater complexity and brings a hint of emotion to what is usually considered an abstraction of reason.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A caption in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about a party to help preserve mansions in Newport, R.I., refered incorrectly to the architect of one, the Elms. He is Horace Trumbauer.

nytimes_articles.headline: They Fell in Love While Wrestling
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The concern of the individual with mortality is indeed the main theme of "Gilgamesh," but I was surprised to see Karin Brothers's emphatic denial of any sexuality at all in the story (Letters, July 18). To the contrary, it reeks with sexuality.

nytimes_articles.headline: Years After Bias Ruling, Yonkers Still a House Divided
nytimes_articles.abstract: MARY MUNSON is weary from the din in the streets, the filth in the elevators and the ever-present threat of drugs and violence that stalks her son and daughter as they travel to and from school. After 10 years of living in this rundown west side neighborhood, Ms. Munson -- who is black and raising her children alone -- said she hopes the next phase of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan will mean an opportunity to finally better her family's circumstances.   Ms. Munson, locking the steel gate behind her in the courtyard of the federally subsidized apartment building for people of low and moderate income where she lives, escorted a visitor to her apartment, to meet Ha-Saun and Tamara, her 15-year-old twins. Once inside, Ms. Munson, who is an executive assistant for Barnes and Noble Bookstores in Manhattan, talked about how the mostly black and Hispanic areas of this city have deteriorated over the years, how her children rarely go outside anymore and about how much she wants to move to a neighborhood where there are lawns, shade trees and safe places to ride a bike.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pope's Remarks to U.S. Bishops
nytimes_articles.abstract: Following is an excerpt from the remarks by Pope John Paul II to American Roman Catholic bishops here today. The text was released by the Vatican.

nytimes_articles.headline: William S. Pierce, Gillian B. Borland
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gillian Beecher Borland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Borland 2d of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to William Stone Pierce, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William S. Pierce of Harrisburg, Pa. The Rev. Dr. John Riegel, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the former residence of the bride's great-grandparents, the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Marvin Sinclaire, in Northville, N.Y.   The bride and the bridegroom graduated from Harvard University, she cum laude and he magna cum laude. She received a master's degree in comparative literature from the University of Michigan, where she is now a Ph.D. candidate.   Her father is a consultant for Universal Management Concepts in Atlanta. Her mother, Prudence Borland, is a sales associate and an architectural designer at Schweppe & Company, a real estate brokerage in Upper Montclair, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Now, Dow Jones?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE POWER AND THE MONEY
Inside The Wall Street Journal.
By Francis X. Dealy Jr.
Illustrated. 374 pp. New York:
Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group.

nytimes_articles.headline: You Never Know What's Below the Surface
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE passion pit of Long Island beaches is Sunken Meadow State Park. "I've come upon a lot of lovers there," said Karen Craft of Sayville. "And they don't stop what they're doing. Even with our spotlights shining and our machines bearing down on them."   In Ms. Craft's line of work, bodies in the throes of passion are but a few of the nighttime obstacles she happens upon. A while back she happened upon half a body washed up on the Jersey Shore. "It was part of a surfer that had been missing," she said. "It caused quite a stir." Fortunately it didn't go through her hopper. Treasures in the Sand    The hoppers, attached to the giant sand-sifting machines that Ms. Craft owns and operates, reveal a wealth of treasures. "I guess the wallet was the biggest find," she said. Not the wallet itself, but the cash inside. How much will be left to the imagination. It's not what Ms. Craft finds on the beaches, it's how well she cleans them that offers her satisfaction.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rail Pass For Baltics
nytimes_articles.abstract: Travelers to Estonia, Latvia or Lithuania can now use the Baltic Rail Card, a pass good for unlimited train travel throughout the three Baltic republics. The passes are available for 8 and 15 days; the prices in early August were $50 and $100, respectively, plus a $15 handling fee for each card if bought in the United States. The American companies that sell the passes said the prices might fluctuate slightly.    The passes, which were introduced last month, may be obtained from Eurocruises and Uniontours, both based in New York.  They are also available at approximately the same prices at railway offices in Finland, Norway and Sweden. In addition to providing unlimited train travel, the passes are good for free reserved sleeping accommodations and discounts on some Baltic ferries and on connecting routes to the Baltic republics from Sweden, Norway, Finland, eastern portions of Germany and parts of Poland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Caroline Fraser and Harold Espen omitted part of the bride's educational background. She has a doctorate in English literature from Harvard.

nytimes_articles.headline: Towns Resist State's 'Big Daddy' Role
nytimes_articles.abstract: FRANK B. CONNOLLY said he got very nervous when the General Assembly was in session. "We don't know what they're going to do there." Those legislators, said John Weichsel, "can say anything and do anything. They have a super home-court advantage." And Lorette Russell warned that if the legislators did not start listening to the folks back home, an amendment to the State Constitution might bring them to their senses.   All three are chief executive officers of Connecticut towns, Mr. Connolly as town manager of North Branford, Mr. Weichsel as town manager of Southington and Ms. Russell as First Selectwoman of Suffield.

nytimes_articles.headline: Louis M. Weinstein and Mia M. Weis
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Roney Weis of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mia Michele Weis, to Louis Michael Weinstein, the son of Rona Weinstein of Westport, Conn., and the late Dr. Edward Weinstein. An October wedding is planned.    Miss Weis, 26, is an administrative assistant in New York at Worms & Company, the Paris merchant bank. She and her fiance graduated from Lehigh University. Her father owns Roney International Inc., a theater-equipment export company in Summit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Mess With Marduk the Magnificent
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE WRESTLER'S CRUEL STUDY By Stephen Dobyns. 426 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Setting Sail, But Not Too Far
nytimes_articles.abstract: Under a tent decorated like a cruise ship, guests dined and danced at Southampton's largest summer benefit, Aug 7.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Steady Habits Included Family Beer Drinking
nytimes_articles.abstract:
CONNECTICUT is the "land of steady habits," where puritans long ago set the tone for temperance and moderation in all things. That, at least, is the stereotype. But as a new exhibition at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford makes vividly clear beer drinking has been one of the state's steadiest habits since the the first European settlers arrived more than 350 years ago.

The Brew Ha-Ha exhibition, on view through Oct. 10, takes a detailed look at the dozens of breweries that operated in Connecticut, especially in the latter half of the 19th century. The breweries, concentrated in New Haven, Hartford, Bridgeport, Meriden and Waterbury, were driven to extinction by Prohibition, which lasted from 1919 to 1933.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Car and Driver Get More in Tune
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AT Lime Rock Park race track in the northwestern corner of the state, 12 students of the BMW/Skip Barber Driving School arrive early on a sunny morning, primed to spend the next nine hours sharpening their driving skills. 

Using high-performance BMW's and advanced driving techniques borrowed from racing, the group will test the outer limits of car control. The objective: to learn safer, more responsible street driving habits. Four instructors, all professional racers, will conduct the course.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Quick-Fix Pill
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In the aftermath of Vincent W. Foster Jr.'s suicide, the report that his doctor in Little Rock, Ark., mailed the White House lawyer antidepressants contributes to a sense of pathos in the case, instead of sounding the alarm at this dangerous but common practice.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Water Rule: An Inch a Week
nytimes_articles.abstract: Keep giving the garden and lawn an inch of water a week, if you are short on rain.   It's too late to prune or fertilize trees and shrubs, because doing either activates new growth, which might not become hardy enough to survive the winter.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Torturer Next Door
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE LIBERTY CAMPAIGN  By Jonathan Dee. 272 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.

nytimes_articles.headline: Indonesia Reduces Separatist's Prison Term
nytimes_articles.abstract: The East Timor separatist leader who was sentenced to life imprisonment in May has had his sentence reduced to 20 years by President Suharto, the Indonesian Government announced Friday.   The separatist, Jose Alexandre Gusmao, who is known as Xanana, had been found guilty of rebellion and firearms possession after a trial in East Timor, which was a Portuguese colony until 1975.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Black Hands of Beijing'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "There is no Chinese equivalent of an Andrei Sakharov, and one of the greatest challenges Chinese dissidents face in winning sympathy abroad is that few Westerners can even pronounce their names," says Nicholas D. Kristof in his review of "Black Hands of Beijing: Lives of Defiance in China's Democracy Movement," by George Black and Robin Munro (July 25).

nytimes_articles.headline: For Playwrights, a New Breed of Angel
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AS THEY begin their second year of producing the Playwright's Theater of East Hampton, a series of low-keyed play readings, Perry and Mitzi Pazer have come to accept one important show business adage: It's not how much you know, but whom you know.

Since its beginning last summer, the Playwright's, part of the Hamptons' burgeoning theater scene, has relied upon informal networking to attract both product and audiences. For example, during the theater's inaugural season, the Pazers mounted a reading of a play by E. L. Doctorow that starred Ben Gazzara, a friend of the writer.

nytimes_articles.headline: Smoker's Lament
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: How fortunate that Eleanor Chard (Letters to Travel, July 18) has found a smoke-free trans-Atlantic carrier so that she won't have to forever forgo the delights of overseas travel. We smokers aren't so lucky. We must live without the everyday pleasures of working in a relaxed atmosphere, eating by a window in a restaurant, enjoying a movie or socializing with friends and family in their homes. We can't even takeg a walk in a park or go to a beach witout being verbally accosted.

nytimes_articles.headline: Liege Casts Its Eye on a Native Son
nytimes_articles.abstract: "ONE would have to say his feet had carried him without his knowledge, by force of habit, to the Brasserie Dauphine. He greeted the proprietor, sniffed the restaurant's warm smell and went over to his corner where he had sat on the bench thousands of times before.    " 'There's andouillette,' Inspector."

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P.'s Role in Trade Pact
nytimes_articles.abstract: Democrats criticized the side agreements to the free-trade pact, but with Republican help, it may pass. News analysis, page 14.

nytimes_articles.headline: Paris Revealed, Down by the Seine
nytimes_articles.abstract: MOST visitors to Paris know that life there began on the river, and if they don't, they soon learn. Not only do they find themselves constantly crossing the Seine to get to the Louvre, the Musee d'Orsay, the great squares and shops of the Right Bank, the Eiffel Tower and famous cafes of the Left Bank, but images of it are everywhere: on postcards, in books of photographs and in Impressionist paintings. Even the city's official logo of a sailing ship pays tribute to this river that is Paris's heart and soul, and that courses through it in a grand seven-mile arc.   This being so, visitors cheat themselves if they confine their experience of the Seine to hurried trips across it on their ways elsewhere.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fanciful Dreams of Africa's Past and Future
nytimes_articles.abstract: The fantasy works of today's African artists often bear no resemblance to those of their ancestors. The dreams of the past are expressed in the miniature clay huts by one contemporary Ivory Coast artist; those of the future in the colorful cardboard skyscrapers by a sculptor in Zaire. And these architectural objects are as dynamic as the human images that characterize so much of traditional African art.    "I'm not sure people in Africa would recognize these objects as art," says Susan Vogel, executive director of the Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, where the works are exhibited in "Home and the World: Architectural Sculpture by Aboudramane and Bodys Isek Kingelez," through Sept. 26. "They are not traditional figures or masks. And since these artists work with their hands, they might be viewed as manual laborers."

nytimes_articles.headline: Walk, Don't Run
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Naomi Campbell slid giggling to the ground, her legs folded under her like a giraffe's, platform shoes seemed doomed. The model's collapse at Vivienne Westwood's fall show in Paris was proof that for modern women, club-sandwich-sized soles are hard to take.    So how come so many designers are proposing that women walk tall? Platform shoes may not reach the dizzy heights of Ms. Westwood's creations, but they are still a big step up from the sensible footwear in which women have been leveling with men.

nytimes_articles.headline: Karen Lonergan, John T. Rollins
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Lonergan of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Marie Lonergan to John Thomas Rollins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rollins of Lake Barrington, Ill. An October wedding is planned.   Ms. Lonergan, a graduate of Kutztown University, is the associate corporate event manager in New York for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Men Were Men (and Women Were Too)
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last year "The Crying Game" had as its secret a woman who turned out to be a man. "Orlando," which opened in June, sketched the life of a character who started out as a man and ended up, four centuries later, a woman.   "The Ballad of Little Jo," opening on Wednesday, is inspired by the story of Josephine Monaghan, who, in order to better herself, lived as a man in the 1800's. Little was known about the woman who was cast out of her family because she had a child out of wedlock. She moved from Buffalo to the West, adopting men's clothing somewhere en route.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Ringwood Journal;
Development Fight Makes Townspeople Uneasy
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THIS Passaic County borough, home of the Wanaque Reservoir, counts its blessings in picturesque lakes and breathtaking views of wooded highlands. But like many another small town, it is finding that those natural wonders are little help at budget time.

Sixty-five percent of the borough is open space -- watershed and parkland, including most of Ringwood State Park -- that produces little in the way of taxes, -- and there is growing pressure to bring in more revenue. Taxes now average $5,200 a household.

nytimes_articles.headline: Asbestos Tests Highlight Agency Flaws
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the heart of the New York City public schools asbestos scandal is a huge and largely hidden bureaucracy with a history of bribery, mismanagement and ineptitude.   It is the division of school facilities, the organization that so mishandled the building of city schools that the Legislature stripped it of construction powers in 1988. Today it is responsible only for maintenance, but it has developed a backlog of 44,000 work orders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Small Pharmacies Struggle to Survive
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AS a boy in the late 1950's, Jack Collins worked as a soda jerk at his family's drugstore in Bridgeport, making cherry Cokes and malted shakes.

But fast food outlets have replaced most drugstore soda fountains, and the days of family-run, independent pharmacies in Connecticut are also vanishing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer Kemp, Matthew Forelli
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jennifer Lynn Kemp, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Kemp of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Briggs Forelli, a son of Sharon B. Forelli of Rowayton, Conn., and Matthew S. Forelli of Westport, Conn. The Rev. John Walsh, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Mead Memorial Chapel on the campus of Middlebury (Vt.) College.   Mrs. Forelli teaches the fifth grade at the Berkeley Carroll School, a private school in Brooklyn. She graduated from Middlebury and received a master's degree in teaching from Columbia University. Her father, an anesthesiologist, is the medical director of the Hartford (Conn.) Surgical Center. Her mother, Lorie Kemp, is a counselor in the Hartford public schools.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
Elusive Figures in Yonkers, Sassy Inflatables in Purchase
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TWO very different artists whose middle name is obsession are figured in separate exhibitions at two museums in the county. Jonathan Borofsky is represented by prints and multiples at the Hudson River Museum, while Pat Oleszko displays outsized and often inflatable performance sets and costume designs at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase. Each artist creates and rules over a total imagined universe. 

During the 1970's, Mr. Borofsky gained renown for his ephemeral brand of conceptual art. He would draw or write directly on a gallery wall and his art would be painted over after he decamped. One of his main subjects was and still is his dreams recounted in his handwriting and often illustrated with charming but naive-looking sketches. Repeating himself is one of his primary artistic strategies, so often the same image shows up in unexpected contexts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lay Off Toronto
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   Harvey Araton's column ("Short-Term Formula Key for Blue Jays," The Times, Aug. 3) on the Blue Jays is one part drivel, two parts envy and three parts sour grapes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bach and Big Brass Band Cap Caramoor Festival
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT Caramoor, the musical stars are still shining as the 48th Festival summer draws to a close. Today at 5:30 P.M., members of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center -- the clarinetist (and artistic director) David Shifrin, the violinist Ani Kavafian, the cellist Gary Hoffman and the pianist David Golub -- disport themselves in trios of Brahms and Beethoven, plus Mendelssohn's D major Sonata for Cello and Piano.   Ushering in the final weekend is a solo recital by the guitarist Manuel Barrueco, making his Caramoor debut with a program on Friday at 8:30 P.M. in the Spanish Courtyard listing works of Weiss, Sor, Rodrigo, Albeniz and Lou Harrison, whose "Air, Sonata in Ishartum, Serenado por Gitaro and Round" sounds like a strong contender for most intriguing title of the year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ian Lustbader, Dana Bernstein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Dana Robin Bernstein, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Theodore Bernstein of Madison, Wis., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Ian Jay Lustbader, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lustbader of New York. Rabbi Eric Polokoff officiated at the St. Moritz in New York.    Dr. Dana Lustbader, 30, is a fellow in critical care at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin, from which she also received a medical degree. Her father, a professor emeritus of electrical and computer engineering at the university, is a consulting engineer based in Madison.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankees' First-Place Meter Still Running
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yogi really said it: Nobody ever goes there because it's always too crowded. He was talking about a restaurant in Minnesota, but yesterday his thesis could have applied to Yankee Stadium.   With a crowd of 52,598 attracted by the combination of a first-place team, a warm summer afternoon and Reggie Jackson Day, the rookie pitcher Domingo Jean found out the hard way what happens when you start out too late.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A theater review last Sunday about "City of Angels" at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport referred incorrectly to three cast members. They were J. T. Cromwell, Carole Crelin and Frank Kosik.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mysteries of One Kind or Another
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT the Jersey City Museum here are exhibitions by Mac Adams, Robin Kahn and Teresa Bramlette, all of them seeming like playlets about mysteries of one kind or another.    In Mr. Adams's photographs, titled "20 Years of Virtual Crime" -- he could have called it "visual" crime -- the mystery ranges from the whodunit to the sociological. The first image, "Three Part Pop," a 1972 triptych in black and white that is hung vertically, warns the viewer with its lighting, as do the opening frames in most "Twilight Zones."

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: Long Island;
Freeport Rolls Up Its Sleeves for Change
nytimes_articles.abstract:
CONFOUNDING skeptics who said it would never work, Philips Associates of Manhattan built a $28 million, 175,000-square-foot shopping mall called Meadowbrook Commons on Sunrise Highway in Freeport two and a half years ago and turned it into one of Long Island's most successful retail ventures. It is fully rented to national chain stores.

"Everyone laughed at us when we did this and told us it was going to be a huge failure because Freeport has this image of being blighted," said Gregg M. Saunders, whose development partners are Philip Pilevsky and Gus Fotos. "Now it is more successful than any of the stores that came there ever thought it would be."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bushwick's Hope Is a Public Project
nytimes_articles.abstract: In their darkest days, the blocks around St. Barbara's Roman Catholic Church in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn absorbed misfortunes of nearly biblical dimensions.    In the mid- to late 1970's, fires coursed through the streets with such regularity that to enable fast evacuation, mothers often dressed their children for bed in street clothes. In the name of urban renewal, the city tore down blocks and blocks of homes, but never built the promised replacements. Packs of wild dogs were often the only signs of life on these streets, the pounding of scavengers pulling copper wire and aluminum fixtures from burned-out buildings the only sound.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hope S. Nichols, David J. Prockop
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hope Sharp Nichols, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Walter Nichols 3d of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to David John Prockop, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Darwin Prockop of Philadelphia. The Rev. Daniel Kincaid performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, N.Y.   Mrs. Prockop, 25, and her husband, 27, are to begin working at the Westminster School in Simsbury, Conn., next month. She will be a development officer and he will be a physics teacher. The bride graduated from Radcliffe College. Her father is a vice president at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Teddy Bears Join Police Officers on Patrol in Bridgeport
nytimes_articles.abstract:
POLICE SGT. WILLIAM CHAPMAN knows the mean streets of Bridgeport all too well. He knows what can happen on a hot summer night, when tempers flare, when someone drinks too much or gets into crack and a domestic dispute erupts.

Often a child is huddled in a corner, crying and watching the police take Dad or Mom away. Sergeant Chapman says he wishes he had always had the special weapon Bridgeport police will soon be carrying along with their guns: teddy bears.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Lisa Schachter and Adam Reisboard referred incorrectly to the married couple. They are Mr. and Mrs. Reisboard.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Manchester, Mr. Barrett
nytimes_articles.abstract: Diana Bennett Manchester, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Manchester of Cohasset, Mass., and Davidson, N.C., was married yesterday to C. Redington Barrett 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Barrett Jr. of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Helen Moore, an Episcopal minister, officiated at Trinity Church in Boston.   The bride graduated from Williams College and received a master's degree in social work from Columbia University. She is a candidate for a master's degree in public and nonprofit management at Yale University. Her father is the president and chief executive of the Kewaunee Scientific Corporation, a manufacturer of laboratory furniture in Statesville, N.C.

nytimes_articles.headline: Worrisome Foursome Betrays The Giants
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Giants tried a three-man defensive front tonight against the Pittsburgh Steelers. Sometimes the Giants tried four men. Other times it looked as if they might try 11 and still would not be able to consistently stuff the run or get to the quarterback.   Injuries have depleted the Giants' pressure up front and the Steelers took full advantage, winning by 23-17 in preseason action before 57,681 fans at Giants Stadium. But there were bright spots for New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Seaside Police, A Hard Day's Night
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S closing in on 2 o'clock of a Sunday morning, and this borough's Police Chief, Tony Schremmer, in jeans and a faded cranberry golf shirt, is walking the Boulevard.    About two hours ago, the last families lugging drowsy children left the noise and neon of boardwalk amusements a block away. In another hour, the next exodus will take place as patrons empty bars and nightclubs along the strip that Chief Schremmer is pacing. Most will make it back to their own beds. But, inevitably, some will wind up spending the night across Barnegat Bay in an Ocean County jail.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ellen Jane Sabin and Herb Subin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Sabin of Weston, Mass., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Ellen Jane Sabin and Herb Subin, a son of Florence Subin of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Bert W. Subin.   Ms. Sabin, 29, is the director of planning and development for the New York Regional Transplant Program in Manhattan, which seeks and distributes organ donations. She and her fiance graduated from Emory University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Ms. Sabin received master's degrees in public administration from New York University and in public health from Harvard University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Who Should Define A City?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hold the moral indignation. Don't blow it on Universal Citywalk, the new pedestrian shopping mall at Universal Studios that has become an instant symbol of our eagerness to seek refuge from urban crisis in escapist entertainment. A lively mix of shops and eating places set within a colorful collage of urbanesque fragments, Citywalk does make every effort to dispel signs of conflict. But it is too rich a subject to toss away in a snit. Along with scoops of Haagen-Dazs and Wolfgang Puck's tasty pizzas, the place serves up fine food for thought.   Citywalk is not in a class with the first-rate buildings Los Angeles architects have produced in recent years. It's in a class with the "Psycho" house. Though created by the Jerde Partnership, a Los Angeles architectural firm, Citywalk's zippy collage of signs and storefronts is more likely to be nominated for an Oscar than for a Pritzker. No one would mistake the mall's overscaled facades for a row of storefronts. Even so, the place is less an escape from Los Angeles than a further mutation of its hyperactive urban genes.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
